description: From Middle English boren, from Old English borian (“to pierce”), from Proto-Germanic *burōną. Compare Danish bore, Norwegian Bokmål bore, Dutch boren, German bohren, Old Norse bora. Cognate with Latin forō (“to bore, to pierce”), Latin feriō (“strike, cut”) and Albanian birë (“hole”). Sense of wearying may come from a figurative use such as "to bore the ears"; compare German drillen.

entries.meaning: A hole drilled or milled through something, or (by extension) its diameter.
The tunnel inside of a gun's barrel through which the bullet travels when fired, or (by extension) its diameter.
A tool, such as an auger, for making a hole by boring.

definitionGroups.group: A capped well drilled to tap artesian water.

entries.meaning: The place where such a well exists.
One who inspires boredom or lack of interest; an uninteresting person.
examples: My neighbour is such a bore when he talks about his coin collection.

entries.meaning: Something dull or uninteresting.
examples: What a bore that movie was! There was no action, and the dialogue was totally uncreative.

entries.meaning: Calibre; importance.

verbs.description: bore (third-person singular simple present bores, present participle boring, simple past and past participle bored)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To inspire boredom in somebody.
examples: Reading books really bores me, films are much more exciting.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make a hole through something.
(intransitive) To make a hole with, or as if with, a boring instrument; to cut a circular hole by the rotary motion of a tool.
examples: to bore for water or oil
An insect bores into a tree.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To form or enlarge (something) by means of a boring instrument or apparatus.
examples: to bore a steam cylinder or a gun barrel; to bore a hole

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make (a passage) by laborious effort, as in boring; to force a narrow and difficult passage through.
examples: to bore one's way through a crowd

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be pierced or penetrated by an instrument that cuts as it turns.
examples: This timber does not bore well.

entries.meaning: (transitive, sports, slang) To push or drive (a boxer into the ropes, a boat out of its course, etc.).
examples: The right hand of Curtis was open too much ; but he nevertheless had the best of the hitting in this round, till Inglis bored him down, out of the ropes.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To push forward in a certain direction with laborious effort.
examples: They take their flight  […]  boring to the west.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To fool; to trick.

description: From Middle English *bore, bare, a borrowing from Old Norse bára (“billow, wave”), from Proto-Germanic *bērō (“that which bears or carries”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰer- (“to bear”). Cognate with Icelandic bára (“billow, wave”), Faroese bára (“billow, wave”). Doublet of bier.

entries.meaning: A sudden and rapid flow of tide occurring in certain rivers and estuaries which rolls up as a wave.
simple past tense of bear
(colloquial) past participle of bear
(proscribed) simple past tense of bare
